Title: Draft of "Will you have the walls [of] the world" published in Leaves of Grass
Subject: Whitman, Walt, 1819-1892. Leaves of grass; American poetry;
Description:
Publications: "Of this broad and majestic universe" published in Edward F. Grier’s edition of the Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts (New York: New York University Press, 1984), p. 1551, with the text taken from Bucke’s Notes and Fragments
Publications: "Will you have the walls [of] the world" published in Leaves of Grass and Other Writings, edited by Michael Moon (New York; London: W.W. Norton & Company, 2000), p. 614, with the text taken from Bucke’s Notes and Fragments (content) Manuscript note written in pencil and revised in pencil and ink on a scrap of white paper, probably before or shortly after 1855. Cf. the Preface of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. Text cancelled by Whitman with a vertical stroke in pencil. On the verso: Will you have the walls [of?] the world; manuscript poem (fragment) written in pencil on a scrap of white paper, possibly early 1850s. Cf. the Preface of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. In Volume III of: Walt Whitman. Holograph manuscript fragments assembled by Dr. Richard Maurice Bucke.
Creator: Whitman, Walt, 1819-1892
Relation: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library

Title: The Modern Colossus
Subject:
Presidential elections
Politicians
Abolition movement
Eagles
Whig Party (U.S.)
Democratic Party (U.S.)
Van Buren, Martin, 1782-1862
Butler, William Orlando, 1791-1880
Calhoun, John C. (John Caldwell), 1782-1850
Cass, Lewis, 1782-1866
Description: Election of 1848. Martin van Buren, ex-President and "Free-Soil" Party candidate is shown trying to bridge the gap between the Whig-Abolition platform and the Democratic platform. Both major parties, the Whigs and the Democrats tried to avoid the slavery question during the campaign, whereas the "Free-Soil" party confronted it head on. The Free-Soilers while losing the Presidential election, won enough Congressional seats in the House to hold the balance of power in the absence of a majority in either of the other parties. Z. Taylor, the Whig candidate, defeated Lewis Cass and Van Buren to win the election. Left to right: Abby Felsom; Martin van Buren; William O. Butler; John C. Calhoun; Lewis Cass.
Publisher: N. Y. : Pub . by Peter Smith, 2 Spruce St.

Title: Punch magazine review of Leaves of Grass
Subject: Whitman, Walt, 1819-1892 -- Criticism and interpretation; Punch (London, England); English wit and humor
Description: Satirical review of the first edition of Leaves of Grass from Punch magazine
column19: AN American Rough, whose name is WALT WHITMAN, and who calls himself a "Kosmos," has been publishing a mad book under the title of Leaves of Grass. We can only say that these Leaves of Grass are fully worthy to be put on a level with that heap of rubbish called Fern Leaves, by FANNY FERN, and similarly "green stuff." The fields of American literature want weeding dreadfully.

Title: First page of The Good Gray Poet
Subject: Whitman, Walt, 1819-1892; O'Connor, William Douglas, 1832-1889; Biography
Description: First page of The Good Gray Poet, a pamphlet written by William Douglas O'Connor as a defense and vindication of Whitman after he was fired from his job at the Department of the Interior in 1865, after Director James Harlan found an 1860 edition of Leaves of Grass and found it morally objectionable. The name The Good Gray Poet would be used to describe Whitman for years to come.
Creator: O'Connor, William Douglas, 1832-1889
